Posts.Content: sara1970 wrote: Hi everyone, Just dx'ed with IDC well-differentiated. No other info from pathology (core biopsy) except that the longest area is 1.3 cm. Of course I'm bummed out about this, but the research I've done in the past few days tells me it could be much worse. I live n NYC and have scheduled consults with Dr. Elisa Port and Dr. Alexandra Heerdt. Can anyone respond here (or PM) if you've worked with either of them, or give me other ideas for consults? One can see me next week, the other not for 3 weeks... I really want to get this started. Is it worth it to wait for that 2nd consult, or am I putting myself in danger by waiting to make a surgical decision?  Also, because I have very small breasts, a mastectomy seems probable. Could anyone point me to any info on the pros and cons of reconstruction?  Thanks in advance.   BMX with TE's on 6-27-11: IDC/LCIS/DCIS on R + LCIS on L Dx 5/27/2011, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: NYC surgeons sara1970 Hortense

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 07:54PM sara1970 wrote: Shirlann,  Terrific - thank you. One of my appointments is at MSK so I'm glad you mentioned that hospital. I agree that it's important to have a seamless operation of people who have their own groove pre-established. Glad you brought up the Breast Book, I've heard about it and will indeed grab a copy. I appreciate your kind reply.

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2011 03:48PM sara1970 wrote: Thanks to you very kind ladies for your informative replies. @cookiegal - checked MSK and Sinai - each have 4 surgeons as part of their BC programs, and MSK's seem more dedicated to breasts, while Mt.Sinai's seem to focus on other things (ie hand surgery) more than breast recon... this is solely based on their online bio's, so I could simply be speculating...
Posts.Title: NYC surgeons sara1970 Hortense

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 02:27PM sara1970 wrote: You guys are amazing - thank you! Shira - are you saying that you believe that MSK has inadequate plastic surgeons, or that you were just disappointed in that they would not give larger implants? Your post implies that you suggest women go elsewhere for recon. I would like to know if anyone here believes that MSK has plastic surgeons who are at the top of their game insofar as the actual surgery itself, drama-free healing, and good rapport with patients. I am not concerned with size.  When someone states that MSK does "not have good options for plastic surgery" that freaks me out... I thought they had one of the top breast cancer teams in the country. Ladies? Help!

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2011 07:24PM sara1970 wrote: @Beeb75 - great to know the vibe at MSK - and I've always wanted to learn how to knit... How did you like Dr. Van Zee?
Posts.Title: NYC surgeons sara1970 Hortense

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2011 07:43AM sara1970 wrote: Ladies - Thank you so very much for all of this feedback and for the PM's I received. Met with both Drs. Port and Heerdt, and honestly I could've gone either way. Obviously both are at the very top of their field. I thought things went astonishingly smoothly at MSK - I ended up seeing a genetic counselor and tested for BRCA, and had an additional MRI. From place to place, it was seamless. That said, I'm choosing MSK. With my relatively young age (40) and likelihood of genetic mutations (1/2 Ashkenazi descent) - I'm opting for a double mast although the 1 cm tumor on the R side is all they can see as of now. Dr. Heerdt works with 3 surgeons, and one of them is Joe Disa - of whom I've only heard good things.  I certainly wouldn't mind some feedback from you ladies if you think I'm making a sound decision. Again, many, MANY thanks to you - the comments and notes I've received have been an amazing resource. -Sara
Posts.Title: NYC surgeons sara1970 Hortense

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2011 12:20AM sara1970 wrote: Guys - Nioxin products have methylparaben in them - a new study out of a California hospital (forget which one) proved that methylparaben diluted the effects of breast cancer treatments - I think they named tamoxifen specifically. I for one have tossed everything in my cabinet that has any paraben in it.  kathylyon wrote: ks mathews -  What Nioxin porducts? Is your hair thin in any areas or the whole head is covered? thanks
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2011 08:07PM sara1970 wrote: Madismommy and Taylor - Best of luck tomorrow - in 24 hours, you'll have one treatment behind you. It's a good feeling - I had a lot more anxiety and sadness leading up to chemo than I do now. You have my warmest wishes in finding comfort and strength - you are not alone! vtEllen - sorry to hear about that new SE! I have heard people talk about a similar feeling on their scalp. Hope someone will chime in soon. Robyn - Your onc knows about what happened during tx, right? I would make sure that your chemo nurse stay with you the entire time for your next one. Best to be safe.  I too, am tired of the pink ribbons and the BC bracelets and all that. I know people mean well, but all that makes me self-conscious - and if there's some time in the day where I can forget about my breast cancer, I really don't need any reminders, ya know?

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 01:39PM sara1970 wrote: Hi ladies, I started chemo about a week ago - one down and seven to go: dose-dense CMF, followed by a neulasta chaser each time. First one wasn't so dreadful - various degrees of fatigue, some difficulty focusing, but staying ahead of other SE's. My tissue expanders started feeling especially hard and clenched-up following the chemo - the onc's nurse swears that it is not related to Chemo - uhhh, okay - sure. They'd been feeling pretty good for the two weeks prior. Anyway, glad to be here. I've enjoyed catching up on the posts on this thread - lots of witty minds and fierce senses of humor.
Posts.Title: August 2011 chemo, anyone w/ me?! vtellen MizMarie

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2011 08:25PM sara1970 wrote: FIRST, ladies I need some help, and I'm sorry if this is "TMI." But, since I've never had a UTI,  yeast infection or any women's issue, I don't know what's happening. I got my second CMF tx on Friday and for the past few days, I've had a slight but consistent 'burn' feeling in my vaginal area. I think I have read that this can happen with chemo. Can anyone tell me what it means, and what I should do?   Deb and jbagley - I have gotten a crazy amount of cysstic acne in only 2 weeks. My Onc is not surprised. I have been using my Proactiv and I've seen a difference in just a few days. Not kidding.   Summergirl, I feel for you... I  have had a good amount of people 'disappear' - not exactly what you spoke of in your post, but another way people can let us down. I hope tomorrow brings you the confidence you deserve   Madismommy - I am so happy that you are doing so well. I know how worried you were during the onset and I just can't help but smile BIG for you right now... Go girl!   MichelleLeo - You are past #3 - nice going - see the finish line? Is it pretty? : )

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2011 11:36PM sara1970 wrote: Hi Rabbit - I am a week out from my dx and I'm no expert, but I can say that a 1 cm mass is on the small side, and that's a good thing! I don't think that the satellites would be indicative of lymph node involvement - apparently that can only be determined via a biopsy which would occur during the surgery. I have been 'cramming' before my surgeon's app't next week, and I definitely feel empowered by the information I've gathered. There's lots of info on this site if you have time to comb through it. Would love it if you could say more about "Mell-MH" which I've never heard of - I'd love info.  Hoping your appointment goes well tomorrow - if at all possible, bring a close friend or family member with you to take notes along with you, or ask the doc if you can audio- tape the conversation. Let us know what happens.
Posts.Title: Birads 5 waiting for biopsy results rabbit rabbit

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 03:37PM sara1970 wrote: Summergirl - thank you for the validation! Unreal how the 'experts' want to deny that this is a result of the chemo. I hope we both feel better soon. Interesting that we are sharing a similar path :) JMULL - thank you alsofor the great tip. I will start that ASAP - my PS's nurse also suggested pushing them around. vtEllen - I am glad your second dose is coming - one more closer to being DONE! It'll happen before we know it!  Are there any ladies here doing CMF? Today is day 9 after my first dose - and I lost an impressive amount of hair today. I did not count the hairs, but I'd guess there were at least 500 between the shower drain and my brush... I thought I'd be able to hold on to my  hair for several more weeks. Anyone experience anything similar?
Posts.Title: August 2011 chemo, anyone w/ me?! vtellen MizMarie

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2011 12:04AM sara1970 wrote: MaryjRN - Sleeping problems are the worst... Ativan definitely helps me in a pinch... Hope it works for you too.   Koalakid - I'm with you on the hair shed... fun, right? How is your husband - on the road to recovery I hope.   Oh Vivie - Sounds like your tech used you as a human pincushion, huh? There's definitely other veins they can use on the lower arm or on the hand - I just had my #2 and I feel like I'm in the race now - closer to the finish - just like you!   OMG Flautalee - great advice on the pain meds, and I'm wishing I were you in a beach chair with a Kindle. That is called enjoying life!    vtEllen and all - FATIGUE: At least 2 nurses and one doctor assure me that my (and your) fatigue will be better controlled if we exercise through this process. Not Olympic training or anything - but as much as our bodies will let us. I am doing 2-lb weights on the arms, a 30-minute walk/jog and leg weight machines - each one a few days a week. Not huge, but something to try and kick thru the fatigue!   Summergirl - I'm glad your son (and sister too?) was able to help you through the shave. You are a rockstar!   Chrys23 -  Are you able to dodge those bone and muscle problems this time? Hope so... I feel you on the sluggish and slow thing for sure....   I just had #2 of 8 CMF (dose-dense regimen) and have stayed ahead of the nausea, and have done the Claritin for dodging the bone pain from the neulasta shot. Hair's shedding, lots of fatigue, and no period for 2+ months (post-BMX).    MY TE's HURT A LOT - after both chemo treatments, and my MO and her nurse refuse to  acknowledge that this could be a SE of chemo. No way, they say. All I know is that it starts to subside several days afterward.. and doesn't feel decent again until it's almost time for the next tx.    Can anyone comment on this TE thing?    Still, I see light at the end of the tunnel. Looking to stay as emotionally clear as often as possible xxoo
Posts.Title: August 2011 chemo, anyone w/ me?! vtellen MizMarie
